* Your total response should be about 150–300 words.

* Submit your completed document in this assignment.

 

NOTE: Be sure to complete all instructions in this activity before submitting it.

--------
Overview
--------

This discussion board is an opportunity for you to share scriptural insights and to learn from your classmates and instructor. Three posts are required throughout the week, designed to build upon each other to help you better understand and apply the scriptures in your life. Your instructor will also be involved in the discussion.

NOTE: Though the actual due date and end date for this discussion fall on the same days as other activities this week, each post in this discussion has a recommended day of the week to post in order for it to be most meaningful for you and your classmates.

------------
Instructions
------------

* To complete this activity, you will share three posts throughout the week by their posted due dates. Follow the individual instructions and examples for the three posts below.

* To see specific grading criteria, select the [3 Dots.] (https://byui.instructure.com/courses/341216/files/147260780/preview)  button at the top of this window and choose Show rubric.

Post 01 Scriptural Insight
--------------------------

Instructions
------------

For this discussion to be most meaningful for you and your classmates, we recommend completing it by Tuesday. 

* Copy and Paste (or type) a passage of scripture from the assigned reading that teaches a meaningful principle.

* Be sure to add the reference to the scripture passage so others can know where to go to find it.

* Identify or restate that principle in your own words, and put it in bold font. See the example below.

* Briefly discuss that principle and its significance to you.

Example
-------

Student 01: "Therefore go, my son, and thou shalt be favored of the Lord because thou hast not murmured." 1 Nephi 3:6. I love 1 Nephi 3:7, but in reading 1 Nephi 3:6 this time, I noticed something I hadn't focused on before. Nephi isn't just blessed for being willing to return to Jerusalem; he's blessed because he does so with a good attitude. After all, Laman and Lemuel make the trip, but they do so begrudgingly. This makes me think that real obedience isn't just completing the action the Lord requires, like going home teaching, he also requires that we obey with the right attitude, like going home teaching joyfully with a desire to bless and uplift others.

 

Post 02 Increased Understanding
-------------------------------

Instructions
------------

For this discussion to be most meaningful for you and your classmates, we recommend completing it by Thursday.

For the second post, you will reply to a classmate's post. Try to add further insight or understanding into one of the posts made by your classmates by sharing a related scripture or a quote from a church leader and then explaining how you feel it adds additional insight or understanding to the scripture or principle being discussed.

Example
-------

Student 02: This is a great insight. It is very hard not to murmur when we face a difficult task that we wish would be a lot easier. In Nephi's case, I learned something in studying the Institute manual that helped me realize how great his sacrifice was in making the trip back to Jerusalem. I just thought it was a three-day trip one way, because 1 Nephi 2:6 talks about when Lehi "had traveled three days in the wilderness . . . ." But the Institute Manual pointed out that Lehi and his family first "came down by the borders near the shore of the Red Sea" (1 Nephi 5:6), which is "about 180 miles through hot, barren country infested anciently by many marauders." Combined with three days of traveling in the wilderness, this means that the whole trip was "at least a twelve-to-fourteen-day trip one way." This was not an easy task, but Nephi does not murmur and I think it is because of his great faith in the Lord and desire to do what was right that he was able to tackle this challenge with a good attitude.

 

Post 03 Personal Application
----------------------------

Instructions
------------

For the third post, you will reply to a classmate's post. Pick a post that you can make a personal application to. You can either share a brief story of when you have seen that principle in your life, identify a way you are currently trying to live that principle, or share an example of a friend or family member who has exemplified that principle to you.

Example
-------

Student 03: I can imagine being quite frustrated if I had first been asked by my dad to leave our city on a 14-day trip and then abruptly being asked to travel back 14 days, retrieve something we left behind, and then being asked to return for another 14-day trip—that's 42 days of traveling! I might think it was a big waste of time and a huge inconvenience. In my life, the prophet has not asked me to accomplish a task like that, but he has asked me to serve as a visiting teacher. I admit that sometimes I feel like this assignment can feel like an inconvenience for me since I have very little free time as a student right now. However, I know that when I have a good attitude about this assignment, it has helped me to love the sisters I visit and to have a better spirit as I've shared messages with them. Sometimes obedience will be inconvenient, but it will always be the right thing to do.

 

NOTE: Be sure to complete all instructions in this activity before considering it complete.

Events.Description: [] (https://byui.instructure.com/courses/48558/files/148480376/preview)

Write a 1-2 page outline for your Change Up essay. Try to include as much detail as possible. 

Example Outline
---------------

* Introduction 

* Give background of your previous experience with the topic and research (especially statistics) that contextualizes your experience

* Give the reader some idea why you chose this experiment out of all the things you could have done

* Remember to write to an audience who has no idea about what a Change Something Up experiment is. Introduce the entire concept to them.

* Methods 

* Explain the rules of the experiment you established for yourself 

* If your rules changed at any point during the experiment, you might explain it here, or you might save that for later in the results section

* Tell what you hoped to gain from it when you chose it

* You might also bring up your research question, tell them what you specifically decided to pay attention to during the experiment

* Results 

* Present, with vivid details, a few select and important events of the experiment 

* Begin this section with a brief overview of the entire experiment and give any hard numbers if you have them available (e.g. “I did my experiment successfully 11 of the 14 days of the experiment.”)

* Present mini-stories or narrative vignettes of moments where you learned something about life or about yourself because of the experiment

* Discussion 

* Reflect on what you learned while doing the experiment

* Don’t introduce any new results here

* Self-evaluate (make guesses about why you succeeded and/or failed)

* Discuss the implications for your life based on the results

* Discuss the trade offs you needed to make in order to make the experiment work (what did you have to stop or start doing in order to be successful)

* Present the results and experience of someone else who did a similar experiment to yours, and compare your results to theirs

* Project into the future what your relationship to your topic will be moving forward

 

As always, bring a paper copy of your essay to class.

Events.Summary: Full draft of Change Up Essay
Events.Description:
Please submit a full-length draft of your Change Up paper here: [Peer Review for Change Up Paper] (https://byui.instructure.com/courses/335578/assignments/14889563)

Your essay should be 5-7 pages long (approximately 1250-1750 words). You should use at least 3-4 sources, at least 1 of which should be an academic source. 

Please use MLA format, including a works cited page and in-text citations. This link will take you to a template for MLA format for Microsoft Word https://images-template-net.webpkgcache.com/doc/-/s/images.template.net/wp-content/uploads/2016/05/02100331/Example-Modern-Language-Cover-Free-Download.doc 

***********************************
Change Something Up Research Essay 
***********************************

**************************
Assignment Sheet - ENG 150
**************************

-----------------
Vital Information
-----------------

Audience: Your Instructor and your peers

Purpose: To practice gathering primary and secondary research and then synthesizing that data into a coherent narrative/reflective essay

Genre: Experiential essay in a modified IMRD format

Stance: Fun but scientific and reliable

Medium: Multimedia alphabetic text (may also images and other media)

Length: Roughly 1250-1750 words

Experiment duration: Two weeks

 

---------------------
Assignment Background
---------------------

A popular genre in contemporary non-fiction is the short-term personal experiment report. Search “30-day experiment” on youtube or google and you will find an endless stream of people changing their lives in an effort to improve and then reporting on the results. 

---------
Your Task
---------

For this assignment you will be doing something similar: You will need to do something out of the ordinary every day for 14 days as a primary research experiment. Before the experiment starts, you’ll make predictions about how the experiment will affect you. During the two weeks, you will keep a journal of field notes about your experience. You will also research if anyone else has tried the same or similar experiment and compare your results to theirs, as well as find out more information about how and why making this change matters or could affect you and how it affects other people typically. You will then turn your writings into a roughly 1250-1750 word reflective research essay written in IMRD (Introduction, Methods, Results, Discussion) format—like a typical lab report, but with narrative elements.

 

Research Requirements 
----------------------

There are three types of sources that you will need to find and incorporate into this assignment: (1) statistics on how many people are doing something similar to what you did for your experiment in order to put your experience in context (2) scientific research on how people are typically affected by doing what you did, and (3) experiences of other people who have done something similar to your experiment (review what happened during their experiment and what their results were, and compare your results to theirs). 

 

Research Requirement

Where to look

Where it will be in the paper

1

Statistics

Pew Research

Statista

Google 

Introduction

2

Scientific Research

Google Scholar

 

Never in the Results section

Introduction (motivated)

Methods

Discussion (make sense)

3

Other people’s experiences

YouTube

Medium

Google search

(avoid advertisements)

Discussion

(methods)

 

Essay Structure
---------------

* Introduction 

* Give background of your previous experience with the topic and research (especially statistics) that contextualizes your experience

* Give the reader some idea why you chose this experiment out of all the things you could have done

* Remember to write to an audience who has no idea about what a Change Something Up experiment is. Introduce the entire concept to them.

* Methods 

* Explain the rules of the experiment you established for yourself 

* If your rules changed at any point during the experiment, you might explain it here, or you might save that for later in the results section

* Tell what you hoped to gain from it when you chose it

* You might also bring up your research question, tell them what you specifically decided to pay attention to during the experiment

* Results 

* Present, with vivid details, a few select and important events of the experiment 

* Begin this section with a brief overview of the entire experiment and give any hard numbers if you have them available (e.g. “I did my experiment successfully 11 of the 14 days of the experiment.”)

* Present mini-stories or narrative vignettes of moments where you learned something about life or about yourself because of the experiment

* Discussion 

* Reflect on what you learned while doing the experiment

* Don’t introduce any new results here

* Self-evaluate (make guesses about why you succeeded and/or failed)

* Discuss the implications for your life based on the results

* Discuss the trade offs you needed to make in order to make the experiment work (what did you have to stop or start doing in order to be successful)

* Present the results and experience of someone else who did a similar experiment to yours, and compare your results to theirs

* Project into the future what your relationship to your topic will be moving forward

------------------------
Choosing Your Experiment
------------------------

For the experiment, you will need to either stop doing something you feel that you do too much of, start doing something you feel you don’t do enough of, or do something you currently do already in a totally different way. In order to be transparent about your efforts, you will want to choose something that a camera could see you doing (or not).

 

Each experience you have during your experiment is worthy of writing about, even (maybe especially) your failures. Although there are no requirements for how much you write in your notes, remember that the more often you write about your experiences during the experiment, the better your final piece will be. Most students write somewhere between 5 and 8 pages of notes over the course of the experiment.

 

Whatever you choose to do, realize that it is going to (and should) disrupt your life, and that you are going to have to make accommodations for that disruption. Your life is already full. If you are choosing to add something to your life, you are going to have to give up something else; likewise, if you are trying to take something out of your life, you are going to have to decide now what is going to fill that space. Your discussion section should talk about the tradeoffs that you had to make in order to change this part of your life up. 

Here are some examples:

-Write in your journal every day

-Meditate each day. You could use a meditation app like Headspace or Calm

-Do a random act of service each day

-Connect with an old friend or a family member through a phone call each day

-Go for a walk each morning or do another form of exercise

-Write a list of 5 things you are grateful for each day

-Meet a new person each day and get to know them for a few minutes

-Go to the temple each day to do an ordinance or just sit on the grounds

-Post your testimony in some form through a message or on social media each day

-Practice a new hobby or a hobby you have forgotten each day. For example, try drawing something every day or play the violin each day if you have not practiced in a while

-Learn something new each day like 10 words of a new language or memorize a verse of scripture each day

-Do a 14-day social media fast

 

-------------------
Managing Your Notes
-------------------

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
There are many options for keeping track of your 14-day experiment. You may choose to keep one file where you will keep your notes, or use a note taking program like Google Keep or something similar. If you write on paper, you could use a spiral-bound notebook or bound journal especially for the project. (I lose paper really quickly myself, so I am not going to do that.) Change Something Up Research Essay 
***********************************

**************************
Assignment Sheet - ENG 150
**************************

-----------------
Vital Information
-----------------

Audience: Your Instructor and your peers

Purpose: To practice gathering primary and secondary research and then synthesizing that data into a coherent narrative/reflective essay

Genre: Experiential essay in a modified IMRD format

Stance: Fun but scientific and reliable

Medium: Multimedia alphabetic text (may also images and other media)

Length: Roughly 1250-1750 words

Experiment duration: Two weeks

 

---------------------
Assignment Background
---------------------

A popular genre in contemporary non-fiction is the short-term personal experiment report. Search “30-day experiment” on youtube or google and you will find an endless stream of people changing their lives in an effort to improve and then reporting on the results. 

---------
Your Task
---------

For this assignment you will be doing something similar: You will need to do something out of the ordinary every day for 14 days as a primary research experiment. Before the experiment starts, you’ll make predictions about how the experiment will affect you. During the two weeks, you will keep a journal of field notes about your experience. You will also research if anyone else has tried the same or similar experiment and compare your results to theirs, as well as find out more information about how and why making this change matters or could affect you and how it affects other people typically. You will then turn your writings into a roughly 1250-1750 word reflective research essay written in IMRD (Introduction, Methods, Results, Discussion) format—like a typical lab report, but with narrative elements.

 

Research Requirements 
----------------------

There are three types of sources that you will need to find and incorporate into this assignment: (1) statistics on how many people are doing something similar to what you did for your experiment in order to put your experience in context (2) scientific research on how people are typically affected by doing what you did, and (3) experiences of other people who have done something similar to your experiment (review what happened during their experiment and what their results were, and compare your results to theirs).

Essay Structure
---------------

* Introduction 

* Give background of your previous experience with the topic and research (especially statistics) that contextualizes your experience

* Give the reader some idea why you chose this experiment out of all the things you could have done

* Remember to write to an audience who has no idea about what a Change Something Up experiment is. Introduce the entire concept to them.

* Methods 

* Explain the rules of the experiment you established for yourself 

* If your rules changed at any point during the experiment, you might explain it here, or you might save that for later in the results section

* Tell what you hoped to gain from it when you chose it

* You might also bring up your research question, tell them what you specifically decided to pay attention to during the experiment

* Results 

* Present, with vivid details, a few select and important events of the experiment 

* Begin this section with a brief overview of the entire experiment and give any hard numbers if you have them available (e.g. “I did my experiment successfully 11 of the 14 days of the experiment.”)

* Present mini-stories or narrative vignettes of moments where you learned something about life or about yourself because of the experiment

* Discussion 

* Reflect on what you learned while doing the experiment

* Don’t introduce any new results here

* Self-evaluate (make guesses about why you succeeded and/or failed)

* Discuss the implications for your life based on the results

* Discuss the trade offs you needed to make in order to make the experiment work (what did you have to stop or start doing in order to be successful)

* Present the results and experience of someone else who did a similar experiment to yours, and compare your results to theirs

* Project into the future what your relationship to your topic will be moving forward

------------------------
Choosing Your Experiment
------------------------

For the experiment, you will need to either stop doing something you feel that you do too much of, start doing something you feel you don’t do enough of, or do something you currently do already in a totally different way. In order to be transparent about your efforts, you will want to choose something that a camera could see you doing (or not).

 

Each experience you have during your experiment is worthy of writing about, even (maybe especially) your failures. Although there are no requirements for how much you write in your notes, remember that the more often you write about your experiences during the experiment, the better your final piece will be. Most students write somewhere between 5 and 8 pages of notes over the course of the experiment.

 

Whatever you choose to do, realize that it is going to (and should) disrupt your life, and that you are going to have to make accommodations for that disruption. Your life is already full. If you are choosing to add something to your life, you are going to have to give up something else; likewise, if you are trying to take something out of your life, you are going to have to decide now what is going to fill that space. Your discussion section should talk about the tradeoffs that you had to make in order to change this part of your life up. 

Here are some examples:

-Write in your journal every day

-Meditate each day. You could use a meditation app like Headspace or Calm

-Do a random act of service each day

-Connect with an old friend or a family member through a phone call each day

-Go for a walk each morning or do another form of exercise

-Write a list of 5 things you are grateful for each day

-Meet a new person each day and get to know them for a few minutes

-Go to the temple each day to do an ordinance or just sit on the grounds

-Post your testimony in some form through a message or on social media each day

-Practice a new hobby or a hobby you have forgotten each day. For example, try drawing something every day or play the violin each day if you have not practiced in a while

-Learn something new each day like 10 words of a new language or memorize a verse of scripture each day

-Do a 14-day social media fast

Managing Your Notes

There are many options for keeping track of your 14-day experiment. You may choose to keep one file where you will keep your notes, or use a note taking program like Google Keep or something similar. If you write on paper, you could use a spiral-bound notebook or bound journal especially for the project. (I lose paper really quickly myself, so I am not going to do that.) The important thing is to keep a lot of notes safe for the whole time. If you lose your notes, writing your paper will be extremely difficult and you will end up with a worse final product. We will have a day in class where you bring your notes, so make sure you have them in a format that works for that.

In your notes, you will want to record meaningful moments: firsts, lasts, mosts, when things feel new or difficult or easy. When and why you choose to give up on the experiment or recommit. Also, you’ll want notes from when you are actually doing the thing you chose to do, and also from when you see it have effects in other parts of your life.

Use of Sources

This is a research assignment. You will be doing both primary research (your own experiences), and secondary research (the experiences and research of others). Part of your job with this assignment is to be meticulous in representing where your outside information is coming from through in-text citations and bibliographic references. You will need to integrate quotes using MLA formatting we have been learning all semester, and include an MLA works cited page.

Post 01 Scriptural Insight
--------------------------

Instructions
------------

For this discussion to be most meaningful for you and your classmates, we recommend completing it by Tuesday (mountain time).

* Copy and Paste (or type) a passage of scripture from the assigned reading that teaches a meaningful principle.

* Be sure to add the reference to the scripture passage so others can know where to go to find it.

* Identify or restate that principle in your own words and put it in bold font. See the example below.

* Briefly discuss that principle and its significance to you.

Example
-------

Student 01: "Therefore go, my son, and thou shalt be favored of the Lord because thou hast not murmured." 1 Nephi 3:6. I love 1 Nephi 3:7, but in reading 1 Nephi 3:6 this time, I noticed something I hadn't focused on before. Nephi isn't just blessed for being willing to return to Jerusalem; he's blessed because he does so with a good attitude. After all, Laman and Lemuel make the trip, but they do so begrudgingly. This makes me think that real obedience isn't just completing the action the Lord requires, like going home teaching, he also requires that we obey with the right attitude, like going home teaching joyfully with a desire to bless and uplift others.

 

Post 02 Increased Understanding
-------------------------------

Instructions
------------

For this discussion to be most meaningful for you and your classmates, we recommend completing it by Thursday (mountain time).

For the second post, you will reply to a classmate's post. Try to add further insight or understanding into one of the posts made by your classmates by sharing a related scripture or a quote from a church leader, and then explaining how you feel it adds additional insight or understanding to the scripture or principle being discussed.

Example
-------

Student 02: This is a great insight. It is very hard not to murmur when we face a difficult task that we wish would be a lot easier. In Nephi's case, I learned something in studying the Institute manual that helped me realize how great his sacrifice was in making the trip back to Jerusalem. I just thought it was a three-day trip one way, because 1 Nephi 2:6 talks about when Lehi "had traveled three days in the wilderness . . . ." But the Institute Manual pointed out that Lehi and his family first "came down by the borders near the shore of the Red Sea" (1 Nephi 5:6), which is "about 180 miles through hot, barren country infested anciently by many marauders." Combined with three days of traveling in the wilderness, this means that the whole trip was "at least a twelve-to-fourteen-day trip one way." This was not an easy task, but Nephi does not murmur and I think it is because of his great faith in the Lord and desire to do what was right that he was able to tackle this challenge with a good attitude.

 

Post 03 Personal Application
----------------------------

Instructions
------------

For the third post, you will reply to a classmate's post. Pick a post that you can make a personal application to. You can share a brief story of when you have seen that principle in your life, identify a way you are currently trying to live that principle, or share an example of a friend or family member who has exemplified that principle to you.

Example
-------

Student 03: I can imagine being quite frustrated if I had first been asked by my dad to leave our city on a 14-day trip and then abruptly being asked to travel back 14 days, retrieve something we left behind, and then being asked to return for another 14-day trip—that's 42 days of traveling! I might think it was a big waste of time and a huge inconvenience. In my life, the prophet has not asked me to accomplish a task like that, but he has asked me to serve as a visiting teacher. I admit that sometimes I feel like this assignment can feel like an inconvenience for me since I have very little free time as a student right now. However, I know that when I have a good attitude about this assignment, it has helped me to love the sisters I visit and to have a better spirit as I've shared messages with them. Sometimes obedience will be inconvenient, but it will always be the right thing to do.

Events.Summary: SW #22 Persuasive Paper Research Questions and Background (Section 9)
Events.Description:
This short writing assignment will help you get a head start on your persuasive research paper

Try to find a topic that you can research and write about for the next few weeks. Do some general research on Google or Wikipedia to learn more about your topic. 

Then, write 1-2 pages about the background of your topic, common arguments you have heard, and questions that you want to answer. You could also write about how your topic fits with the five stasis points.

For example, if you chose to write about homeschooling, you might include these questions and your initial answers:

Facts: How many children are being homeschooled in the USA?

Definition: What counts as home-schooling? What about online schools, dual-enrollment, etc. 

Cause/effect: Why is homeschooling becoming more popular? 

Evaluation: Does homeschooling help or harm kids academically? Does it help or harm kids socially?

Proposal: Should there be more government oversight for homeschooling? Should parents get tax money to help them educate their kids? Should parents choose homeschooling? 

 

As always, bring a paper copy to class.

Here are some topics that you might want to choose, but you are not limited to these options:

-Is online dating a good way to meet a spouse?  

-Is it better to grow up with lots of siblings or few siblings?

-Is it better to get married at a younger age or an older age? 

-What are the solutions to the drug and Fentanyl problems in the US?

-Should transgender athletes compete with female athletes? 

-Should states ban hormone blockers, cross-sex hormones, and/or sex-change surgeries for minors? 

-What can be done about illegal immigration?  

-Should the federal government forgive student loan debt? 

-What is the value of a college degree? 

-Is nuclear power safe and effective, or should nuclear power plants be shut down? 

-What are the effects of smartphones, screen time, and/or social media on mental health?

-Is physical discipline like spanking effective in parenting?

-Should marijuana be legalized recreationally in every state? 

-Should we raise the federal minimum wage to $15?

-Should states ban abortion? If so, at what stage in the pregnancy? How should abortion laws be enforced? 

-Should colleges practice affirmative action in admissions? Should employers use affirmative action in hiring? 

-What is the best solution for homelessness? Is "housing first" a good policy? 

-What is the best solution to crime? What are the merits of criminal justice reform, bail reform, and "harm reduction" policies? 

-Should California and other states ban the sale of new gas cars by 2035? Should the government continue to subsidize the sale of electric vehicles with tax breaks? 

-Should the government subsidize the sale of solar panels for homeowners? 

-What are the effects of religion on teenagers and young adults? 

-Should all states ban minors from tanning beds? 

-Should social media platforms censor speech? Should hate speech be banned? Should certain books be taken out of school libraries? 

-Is homeschooling good for kids? 

-What are the benefits or harms of standardized testing? 

-What forms of exercise are the most effective? Is weight training more effective than aerobic exercise? What about things like HIT, supplements, etc.? 

-What are the effects of gratitude on happiness?

Read chapter 5 of our book They Say / I Say. 

You can access a free online version of the book here: [https://archive.org/details/they-say-i-say-5th-edition/page/n1/mode/2upLinks to an external site.] (https://archive.org/details/they-say-i-say-5th-edition/page/n1/mode/2up) or here [https://archive.org/details/theysayisay3rdedition/page/n29/mode/2upLinks to an external site.] (https://archive.org/details/theysayisay3rdedition/page/n29/mode/2up)

For this short writing exercise, write an outline for your persuasive paper. Make it as detailed as you can at this stage of your writing process. 

You may want to use one of the following patterns to shape your outline:

Problem/Solution

First, define the problem

Then, offer your solution (you could compare your solution to other solutions that have been tried or proposed)

Best for a clear problem with many proposed solutions, like drug addiction.

 

Five Stasis Points

Fact

Definition

Cause/effect

Evaluation

Proposal

Best for a topic people don’t already know a lot about, like the Tigray rebellion

 

Delayed Thesis

Show both sides of the argument first, then give your opinion late in the paper

Best for emotionally charged controversies where both sides are stubborn, like abortion

 

They say / I say

Start with the opposing side

Best for contrarian takes and strong opinions, like birth rate decline

 

Traditional

Like the five-paragraph essay

Start with the thesis and support it with reasons and evidence

Best for a topic you have a strong opinion about, like gun control. You can deal with the naysayers later.

 

Evaluation based

Set up the criteria of evaluation

Best for evaluation arguments like “is homeschooling good for kids?”

 

Proposal based

Start with your proposal

Then defend your proposal from naysayers by talking about feasibility, justice, effectiveness, etc.

Best for proposals like “we should ban fracking”

Events.Summary: SW #24 Sources for the Persuasive Paper (Section 9)
Events.Description:
Write a 1-2 page paper with at least 6 sources, 4 of which should be peer-reviewed, academic articles.

For each source, include the MLA citation and a few sentences of summary about what the source says and where you might use it.

Useful resources include [scholar.google.com] (http://scholar.google.com) and [library.byui.edu] (http://library.byui.edu) 

As you search for sources, think about which sources will fit into which parts of your paper. 

Here are some of the ideas for outlining that we looked at in class:

Different ideas for organizing your paper:

Problem/Solution: Good for topics that not everyone knows are big problems

-A big chunk of the paper should establish the size/importance of the problem

-Then you give your solutions

-Naysayers could be saying “it’s not a real problem,” or “That solution won’t work”

5 Stasis Points: Good for most topics, especially if people are not aware of them

-Facts, definitions, cause and effect, evaluation, and proposal

-Consider ending with a proposal, no matter what organization you use

Evaluation or Proposal focus: good for specific topics

-For evaluation, establish criteria

-For proposal, show that your solution is better than the alternatives and feasible

Delayed Thesis: Good for highly controversial topics

-show pros and cons of both sides

-Eventually share what you think is the stronger side

They Say / I Say: Good for most topics, especially if there are a lot of opinions out there

-Start with what others are saying, respond like a conversation, deal with naysayers

Naysayer Focus: Good for controversial topics, or for readers who disagree with you

-Bring up and answer a series of naysayers

Traditional: works for many topics, especially if you have a lot of objective evidence

-Thesis, reasons, evidence

-Include naysayers

Read chapter 8 our book They Say / I Say. 

You can access a free online version of the book here: [https://archive.org/details/they-say-i-say-5th-edition/page/n1/mode/2upLinks to an external site.] (https://archive.org/details/they-say-i-say-5th-edition/page/n1/mode/2up) or here [https://archive.org/details/theysayisay3rdedition/page/n29/mode/2upLinks to an external site.] (https://archive.org/details/theysayisay3rdedition/page/n29/mode/2up)

--------
Overview
--------

This discussion board is an opportunity for you to share scriptural insights and to learn from your classmates and instructor. Three posts are required throughout the week, designed to build upon each other to help you better understand and apply the scriptures in your life. Your instructor will also be involved in the discussion.

NOTE: Though the actual due date and end date for this discussion fall on the same days as other activities this week, each post in this discussion has a recommended day of the week to post in order for it to be most meaningful for you and your classmates.

------------
Instructions
------------

* To complete this activity, you will share three posts throughout the week by their posted due dates. Follow the individual instructions and examples for the three posts below.

* To see specific grading criteria, select the [3 Dots.] (https://byui.instructure.com/courses/341216/files/147260780/preview)  button at the top of this window and choose Show rubric.

Post 01 Scriptural Insight
--------------------------

Instructions
------------

For this discussion to be most meaningful for you and your classmates, we recommend completing it by Tuesday (mountain time).

* Copy and Paste (or type) a passage of scripture from the assigned reading that teaches a meaningful principle.

* Be sure to add the reference to the scripture passage so others can know where to go to find it.

* Identify or restate that principle in your own words and put it in bold font. See the example below.

* Briefly discuss that principle and its significance to you.

Example
-------

Student 01: "Therefore go, my son, and thou shalt be favored of the Lord because thou hast not murmured." 1 Nephi 3:6. I love 1 Nephi 3:7, but in reading 1 Nephi 3:6 this time, I noticed something I hadn't focused on before. Nephi isn't just blessed for being willing to return to Jerusalem; he's blessed because he does so with a good attitude. After all, Laman and Lemuel make the trip, but they do so begrudgingly. This makes me think that real obedience isn't just completing the action the Lord requires, like going home teaching, he also requires that we obey with the right attitude, like going home teaching joyfully with a desire to bless and uplift others.

 

Post 02 Increased Understanding
-------------------------------

Instructions
------------

For this discussion to be most meaningful for you and your classmates, we recommend completing it by Thursday (mountain time).

For the second post, you will reply to a classmate's post. Try to add further insight or understanding into one of the posts made by your classmates by sharing a related scripture or a quote from a church leader, and then explaining how you feel it adds additional insight or understanding to the scripture or principle being discussed.

Example
-------

Student 02: This is a great insight. It is very hard not to murmur when we face a difficult task that we wish would be a lot easier. In Nephi's case, I learned something in studying the Institute manual that helped me realize how great his sacrifice was in making the trip back to Jerusalem. I just thought it was a three-day trip one way because 1 Nephi 2:6 talks about when Lehi "had traveled three days in the wilderness . . ." But the Institute Manual pointed out that Lehi and his family first "came down by the borders near the shore of the Red Sea" (1 Nephi 5:6), which is "about 180 miles through a hot, barren country infested anciently by many marauders." Combined with three days of traveling in the wilderness, this means that the whole trip was "at least a twelve-to-fourteen-day trip one way." This was not an easy task, but Nephi does not murmur and I think it is because of his great faith in the Lord and desire to do what was right that he was able to tackle this challenge with a good attitude.

 

Post 03 Personal Application
----------------------------

Instructions
------------

For the third post, you will reply to a classmate's post. Pick a post that you can make a personal application to. You can share a brief story of when you have seen that principle in your life, identify a way you are currently trying to live that principle, or share an example of a friend or family member who has exemplified that principle to you.

Example
-------

Student 03: I can imagine being quite frustrated if I had first been asked by my dad to leave our city on a 14-day trip and then abruptly being asked to travel back 14 days, retrieve something we left behind, and then being asked to return for another 14-day trip—that's 42 days of traveling! I might think it was a big waste of time and a huge inconvenience. In my life, the prophet has not asked me to accomplish a task like that, but he has asked me to serve as a visiting teacher. I admit that sometimes I feel like this assignment can feel like an inconvenience for me since I have very little free time as a student right now. However, I know that when I have a good attitude about this assignment, it has helped me to love the sisters I visit and to have a better spirit as I've shared messages with them. Sometimes obedience will be inconvenient, but it will always be the right thing to do.

 

NOTE: Be sure to complete all instructions in this activity before considering it complete.

-----------------
Vital Information
-----------------

* Audience: English 150 Instructor

* Purpose: Demonstrate your ability to (1) integrate sources according to academic standards and (2) analyze your experience with the writing process in ENG 150, and (3) provide evidence for how this course helped you become a more effective communicator.

* Length: 300-550 words (about 1.5-2 pages)

------------
Instructions
------------

* Brainstorm a response to the following questions:

* What misconceptions or concerns did you have about writing before taking ENG 150?

* What have you learned this semester about the writing process?

* What have you learned about how to be an effective communicator?

* Study the following resources and choose quotes that connect with your learning experience in ENG 150. You must use at least one quote from L. Lennie Irvin's "What Is 'Academic' Writing?" and one quote from E. Shelley Reid’s “Ten Ways to Think About Writing: Metaphoric Musings for College Writing Students.” You are, of course, welcome to include more than just one quote from each article and to summarize or paraphrase ideas from the articles as well.

*

* [What Is Academic Writing_Irvin_ENG150 Common Assessment Excerpt.pdf] (https://byui.instructure.com/courses/335578/files/148015482?wrap=1) 

* [Ten Ways To Think About Writing_Common Assessment Excerpt.pdf] (https://byui.instructure.com/courses/335578/files/148015484?wrap=1) 

* Begin writing a 1.5–2 page reflection paper. Follow these instructions as you do so:

* Write a rough draft or outline of your reflection. There are many ways to organize a reflection essay, but the basic organization should include the following.

* Introduction: Describe your mindset at the beginning of ENG 150, and share some of the misconceptions or initial concerns you may have had. You may or may not use a quote as part of the introduction.

* Body Paragraph: Describe what you learned and how it helped you overcome a misconception or concern about writing. You may or may not incorporate a quote from an outside source here, but you will need to include two quotes from different sources somewhere in the reflection.

* Body Paragraph: Describe another thing you learned and how it helped you overcome either the same misconception/concern or a different misconception/concern about writing.

* More Body Paragraphs: Add more descriptions of your learning and growth as needed/desired.

* Conclusion: Briefly summarize the most important things you learned, and describe how you plan to use what you've learned beyond this class. In other words, how has this class helped you to be an effective communicator in future writing situations?

* Last, but not least, consider formatting. What have you learned about expectations for academic style (usually MLA or APA)? What have you learned about citing sources?  Be sure to show (and not just tell) your instructor what you’ve learned.

* Submit your completed reflection by the due date.

Helpful Hints
-------------

* Be sure to support your ideas about learning to write in ENG 150 with meaningful and specific evidence from your experiences in the course. In other words, don't just say, "This class taught me how to write." Instead, give specific examples of what you didn't know (or thought you knew) and then describe how and why you changed throughout the semester. Be sure to mention specifics like assigned readings, homework, conferences, and other activities that either helped (or didn't help) you along the way.

* Be sure to format the citations correctly at the end of your essay. The final citations for the articles should look like this:

APA Format

Irvin, L. L. (2010). What is "academic" writing? In C. Lowe and P. Zemaliansky (Eds.), Writing Spaces: Readings on Writing, vol. 1. Parlor Press.

Reid, E. S. (2011). Ten ways to think about writing: Metaphoric musings for college writing students. In C. Lowe and P. Zemaliansky (Eds.), Writing Spaces: Readings on Writing, vol. 2. Parlor Press.

MLA Format

Irvin, L. Lennie. “What Is 'Academic' Writing?” Writing Spaces: Readings on Writing, edited by Charles Lowe and Pavel Zemlianksky, vol. 1, Parlor Press, 2010. WritingSpaces.org, https://writingspaces.org/past-volumes/a-students-guide-to-collaborative-writing-technologies/.

Reid, E. Shelley. “Ten Ways to Think about Writing: Metaphoric Musings for College Writing Students. Writing Spaces: Readings on Writing, edited by Charles Lowe and Pavel Zemlianksky, vol. 2, Parlor Press, 2010. WritingSpaces.org, https://writingspaces.org/past-volumes/a-students-guide-to-collaborative-writing-technologies/.

--------
Overview
--------

This discussion board is an opportunity for you to share scriptural insights and to learn from your classmates and instructor. Three posts are required throughout the week, designed to build upon each other to help you better understand and apply the scriptures in your life. Your instructor will also be involved in the discussion.

NOTE: Though the actual due date and end date for this discussion fall on the same days as other activities this week, each post in this discussion has a recommended day of the week to post in order for it to be most meaningful for you and your classmates.

------------
Instructions
------------

* To complete this activity, you will share three posts throughout the week by their posted due dates. Follow the individual instructions and examples for the three posts below.

* To see specific grading criteria, select the [3 Dots.] (https://byui.instructure.com/courses/341216/files/147260780/preview)  button at the top of this window and choose Show rubric.

Post 01 Scriptural Insight
--------------------------

Instructions
------------

For this discussion to be most meaningful for you and your classmates, we recommend completing it by Tuesday. 

* Copy and Paste (or type) a passage of scripture from the assigned reading that teaches a meaningful principle.

* Be sure to add the reference to the scripture passage so others can know where to go to find it.

* Identify or restate that principle in your own words, and put it in bold font. See the example below.

* Briefly discuss that principle and its significance to you.

Example
-------

Student 01: "Therefore go, my son, and thou shalt be favored of the Lord because thou hast not murmured." 1 Nephi 3:6. I love 1 Nephi 3:7, but in reading 1 Nephi 3:6 this time, I noticed something I hadn't focused on before. Nephi isn't just blessed for being willing to return to Jerusalem; he's blessed because he does so with a good attitude. After all, Laman and Lemuel make the trip, but they do so begrudgingly. This makes me think that real obedience isn't just completing the action the Lord requires, like going home teaching, he also requires that we obey with the right attitude, like going home teaching joyfully with a desire to bless and uplift others.

 

Post 02 Increased Understanding
-------------------------------

Instructions
------------

For this discussion to be most meaningful for you and your classmates, we recommend completing it by Thursday.

For the second post, you will reply to a classmate's post. Try to add further insight or understanding into one of the posts made by your classmates by sharing a related scripture or a quote from a church leader and then explaining how you feel it adds additional insight or understanding to the scripture or principle being discussed.

Example
-------

Student 02: This is a great insight. It is very hard not to murmur when we face a difficult task that we wish would be a lot easier. In Nephi's case, I learned something in studying the Institute manual that helped me realize how great his sacrifice was in making the trip back to Jerusalem. I just thought it was a three-day trip one way, because 1 Nephi 2:6 talks about when Lehi "had traveled three days in the wilderness . . . ." But the Institute Manual pointed out that Lehi and his family first "came down by the borders near the shore of the Red Sea" (1 Nephi 5:6), which is "about 180 miles through hot, barren country infested anciently by many marauders." Combined with three days of traveling in the wilderness, this means that the whole trip was "at least a twelve-to-fourteen-day trip one way." This was not an easy task, but Nephi does not murmur and I think it is because of his great faith in the Lord and desire to do what was right that he was able to tackle this challenge with a good attitude.

 

Post 03 Personal Application
----------------------------

Instructions
------------

For the third post, you will reply to a classmate's post. Pick a post that you can make a personal application to. You can either share a brief story of when you have seen that principle in your life, identify a way you are currently trying to live that principle, or share an example of a friend or family member who has exemplified that principle to you.

Example
-------

Student 03: I can imagine being quite frustrated if I had first been asked by my dad to leave our city on a 14-day trip and then abruptly being asked to travel back 14 days, retrieve something we left behind, and then being asked to return for another 14-day trip—that's 42 days of traveling! I might think it was a big waste of time and a huge inconvenience. In my life, the prophet has not asked me to accomplish a task like that, but he has asked me to serve as a visiting teacher. I admit that sometimes I feel like this assignment can feel like an inconvenience for me since I have very little free time as a student right now. However, I know that when I have a good attitude about this assignment, it has helped me to love the sisters I visit and to have a better spirit as I've shared messages with them. Sometimes obedience will be inconvenient, but it will always be the right thing to do.

 

NOTE: Be sure to complete all instructions in this activity before considering it complete.

I admit that sometimes I feel like this assignment can feel like an inconvenience for me since I have very little free time as a student right now. However, I know that when I have a good attitude about this assignment, it has helped me to love the sisters I visit and to have a better spirit as I've shared messages with them. Sometimes obedience will be inconvenient, but it will always be the right thing to do.

Instead of scholarly sources, this time look for statistics and stories that fit well with your project. 

For example, if your experiment involves meditation, you could find numbers about how many people in the USA meditate regularly. Some helpful sites might include [www.pewresearch.org] (http://www.pewresearch.org), [www.statista.com] (https://www.statista.com/), and simple google searches.

Events.Summary: SW #17 Academic Research for Change Up Essay (Section 9)
Events.Description:
For this short writing assignment, you will summarize three academic sources you could use in your Change Up essay.

To find your sources, I suggest using scholar.google.com or library.byui.edu. 

For each source, give a summary in a bullet point for each of the main sections. Most scholarly papers follow the IMRAD format with sections titled Introduction, Methods, Results, Analysis, and Discussion. 

You should finish with three sources with five bullet points each.

Write a 1-2 page outline for your Change Up essay. Try to include as much detail as possible. 

Example Outline
---------------

* Introduction 

* Give background of your previous experience with the topic and research (especially statistics) that contextualizes your experience

* Give the reader some idea why you chose this experiment out of all the things you could have done

* Remember to write to an audience who has no idea about what a Change Something Up experiment is. Introduce the entire concept to them.

* Methods 

* Explain the rules of the experiment you established for yourself 

* If your rules changed at any point during the experiment, you might explain it here, or you might save that for later in the results section

* Tell what you hoped to gain from it when you chose it

* You might also bring up your research question, tell them what you specifically decided to pay attention to during the experiment

* Results 

* Present, with vivid details, a few select and important events of the experiment 

* Begin this section with a brief overview of the entire experiment and give any hard numbers if you have them available (e.g. “I did my experiment successfully 11 of the 14 days of the experiment.”)

* Present mini-stories or narrative vignettes of moments where you learned something about life or about yourself because of the experiment

* Discussion 

* Reflect on what you learned while doing the experiment

* Don’t introduce any new results here

* Self-evaluate (make guesses about why you succeeded and/or failed)

* Discuss the implications for your life based on the results

* Discuss the trade offs you needed to make in order to make the experiment work (what did you have to stop or start doing in order to be successful)

* Present the results and experience of someone else who did a similar experiment to yours, and compare your results to theirs

* Project into the future what your relationship to your topic will be moving forward

 

As always, bring a paper copy of your essay to class.
Write at least two questions, answers, or comments.

***********************************
Change Something Up Research Essay 
***********************************

**************************
Assignment Sheet - ENG 150
**************************

-----------------
Vital Information
-----------------

Audience: Your Instructor and your peers

Purpose: To practice gathering primary and secondary research and then synthesizing that data into a coherent narrative/reflective essay

Genre: Experiential essay in a modified IMRD format

Stance: Fun but scientific and reliable

Medium: Multimedia alphabetic text (may also images and other media)

Length: Roughly 1250-1750 words

Experiment duration: Two weeks

 

---------------------
Assignment Background
---------------------

A popular genre in contemporary non-fiction is the short-term personal experiment report. Search “30-day experiment” on youtube or google and you will find an endless stream of people changing their lives in an effort to improve and then reporting on the results. 

---------
Your Task
---------

For this assignment you will be doing something similar: You will need to do something out of the ordinary every day for 14 days as a primary research experiment. Before the experiment starts, you’ll make predictions about how the experiment will affect you. During the two weeks, you will keep a journal of field notes about your experience. You will also research if anyone else has tried the same or similar experiment and compare your results to theirs, as well as find out more information about how and why making this change matters or could affect you and how it affects other people typically. You will then turn your writings into a roughly 1250-1750 word reflective research essay written in IMRD (Introduction, Methods, Results, Discussion) format—like a typical lab report, but with narrative elements.

 

Research Requirements 
----------------------

There are three types of sources that you will need to find and incorporate into this assignment: (1) statistics on how many people are doing something similar to what you did for your experiment in order to put your experience in context (2) scientific research on how people are typically affected by doing what you did, and (3) experiences of other people who have done something similar to your experiment (review what happened during their experiment and what their results were, and compare your results to theirs). 

 

Research Requirement

Where to look

Where it will be in the paper

1

Statistics

Pew Research

Statista

Google 

Introduction

2

Scientific Research

Google Scholar

 

Never in the Results section

Introduction (motivated)

Methods

Discussion (make sense)

3

Other people’s experiences

YouTube

Medium

Google search

(avoid advertisements)

Discussion

(methods)

 

Essay Structure
---------------

* Introduction 

* Give background of your previous experience with the topic and research (especially statistics) that contextualizes your experience

* Give the reader some idea why you chose this experiment out of all the things you could have done

* Remember to write to an audience who has no idea about what a Change Something Up experiment is. Introduce the entire concept to them.

* Methods 

* Explain the rules of the experiment you established for yourself 

* If your rules changed at any point during the experiment, you might explain it here, or you might save that for later in the results section

* Tell what you hoped to gain from it when you chose it

* You might also bring up your research question, tell them what you specifically decided to pay attention to during the experiment

* Results 

* Present, with vivid details, a few select and important events of the experiment 

* Begin this section with a brief overview of the entire experiment and give any hard numbers if you have them available (e.g. “I did my experiment successfully 11 of the 14 days of the experiment.”)

* Present mini-stories or narrative vignettes of moments where you learned something about life or about yourself because of the experiment

* Discussion 

* Reflect on what you learned while doing the experiment

* Don’t introduce any new results here

* Self-evaluate (make guesses about why you succeeded and/or failed)

* Discuss the implications for your life based on the results

* Discuss the trade offs you needed to make in order to make the experiment work (what did you have to stop or start doing in order to be successful)

* Present the results and experience of someone else who did a similar experiment to yours, and compare your results to theirs

* Project into the future what your relationship to your topic will be moving forward

------------------------
Choosing Your Experiment
------------------------

For the experiment, you will need to either stop doing something you feel that you do too much of, start doing something you feel you don’t do enough of, or do something you currently do already in a totally different way. In order to be transparent about your efforts, you will want to choose something that a camera could see you doing (or not).

 

Each experience you have during your experiment is worthy of writing about, even (maybe especially) your failures. Although there are no requirements for how much you write in your notes, remember that the more often you write about your experiences during the experiment, the better your final piece will be. Most students write somewhere between 5 and 8 pages of notes over the course of the experiment.

 

Whatever you choose to do, realize that it is going to (and should) disrupt your life, and that you are going to have to make accommodations for that disruption. Your life is already full. If you are choosing to add something to your life, you are going to have to give up something else; likewise, if you are trying to take something out of your life, you are going to have to decide now what is going to fill that space. Your discussion section should talk about the tradeoffs that you had to make in order to change this part of your life up. 

Here are some examples:

-Write in your journal every day

-Meditate each day. You could use a meditation app like Headspace or Calm

-Do a random act of service each day

-Connect with an old friend or a family member through a phone call each day

-Go for a walk each morning or do another form of exercise

-Write a list of 5 things you are grateful for each day

-Meet a new person each day and get to know them for a few minutes

-Go to the temple each day to do an ordinance or just sit on the grounds

-Post your testimony in some form through a message or on social media each day

-Practice a new hobby or a hobby you have forgotten each day. For example, try drawing something every day or play the violin each day if you have not practiced in a while

-Learn something new each day like 10 words of a new language or memorize a verse of scripture each day

-Do a 14-day social media fast

 

-------------------
Managing Your Notes
-------------------

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
There are many options for keeping track of your 14-day experiment. You may choose to keep one file where you will keep your notes, or use a note taking program like Google Keep or something similar. If you write on paper, you could use a spiral-bound notebook or bound journal especially for the project. (I lose paper really quickly myself, so I am not going to do that.) The important thing is to keep a lot of notes safe for the whole time. If you lose your notes, writing your paper will be extremely difficult and you will end up with a worse final product. We will have a day in class where you bring your notes, so make sure you have them in a format that works for that. 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

In your notes, you will want to record meaningful moments: firsts, lasts, mosts, when things feel new or difficult or easy. When and why you choose to give up on the experiment or recommit. Also, you’ll want notes from when you are actually doing the thing you chose to do, and also from when you see it have effects in other parts of your life. 

--------------
Use of Sources
--------------

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
This is a research assignment. You will be doing both primary research (your own experiences), and secondary research (the experiences and research of others). Part of your job with this assignment is to be meticulous in representing where your outside information is coming from through in-text citations and bibliographic references. You will need to integrate quotes using MLA formatting we have been learning all semester, and include an MLA works cited page.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

* You might also bring up your research question, tell them what you specifically decided to pay attention to during the experiment

* Results 

* Present, with vivid details, a few select and important events of the experiment 

* Begin this section with a brief overview of the entire experiment and give any hard numbers if you have them available (e.g. “I did my experiment successfully 11 of the 14 days of the experiment.”)

* Present mini-stories or narrative vignettes of moments where you learned something about life or about yourself because of the experiment

* Discussion 

* Reflect on what you learned while doing the experiment

* Don’t introduce any new results here

* Self-evaluate (make guesses about why you succeeded and/or failed)

* Discuss the implications for your life based on the results

* Discuss the trade offs you needed to make in order to make the experiment work (what did you have to stop or start doing in order to be successful)

* Present the results and experience of someone else who did a similar experiment to yours, and compare your results to theirs

* Project into the future what your relationship to your topic will be moving forward

------------------------
Choosing Your Experiment
------------------------

For the experiment, you will need to either stop doing something you feel that you do too much of, start doing something you feel you don’t do enough of, or do something you currently do already in a totally different way. In order to be transparent about your efforts, you will want to choose something that a camera could see you doing (or not).

 

Each experience you have during your experiment is worthy of writing about, even (maybe especially) your failures. Although there are no requirements for how much you write in your notes, remember that the more often you write about your experiences during the experiment, the better your final piece will be. Most students write somewhere between 5 and 8 pages of notes over the course of the experiment.

 

Whatever you choose to do, realize that it is going to (and should) disrupt your life, and that you are going to have to make accommodations for that disruption. Your life is already full. If you are choosing to add something to your life, you are going to have to give up something else; likewise, if you are trying to take something out of your life, you are going to have to decide now what is going to fill that space. Your discussion section should talk about the tradeoffs that you had to make in order to change this part of your life up. 

Here are some examples:

-Write in your journal every day

-Meditate each day. You could use a meditation app like Headspace or Calm

-Do a random act of service each day

-Connect with an old friend or a family member through a phone call each day

-Go for a walk each morning or do another form of exercise

-Write a list of 5 things you are grateful for each day

-Meet a new person each day and get to know them for a few minutes

-Go to the temple each day to do an ordinance or just sit on the grounds

-Post your testimony in some form through a message or on social media each day

-Practice a new hobby or a hobby you have forgotten each day. For example, try drawing something every day or play the violin each day if you have not practiced in a while

-Learn something new each day like 10 words of a new language or memorize a verse of scripture each day

-Do a 14-day social media fast

Managing Your Notes

There are many options for keeping track of your 14-day experiment. You may choose to keep one file where you will keep your notes, or use a note taking program like Google Keep or something similar. If you write on paper, you could use a spiral-bound notebook or bound journal especially for the project. (I lose paper really quickly myself, so I am not going to do that.) The important thing is to keep a lot of notes safe for the whole time. If you lose your notes, writing your paper will be extremely difficult and you will end up with a worse final product. We will have a day in class where you bring your notes, so make sure you have them in a format that works for that.

In your notes, you will want to record meaningful moments: firsts, lasts, mosts, when things feel new or difficult or easy. When and why you choose to give up on the experiment or recommit. Also, you’ll want notes from when you are actually doing the thing you chose to do, and also from when you see it have effects in other parts of your life.

Use of Sources

This is a research assignment. You will be doing both primary research (your own experiences), and secondary research (the experiences and research of others). Part of your job with this assignment is to be meticulous in representing where your outside information is coming from through in-text citations and bibliographic references. You will need to integrate quotes using MLA formatting we have been learning all semester, and include an MLA works cited page.

Events.Summary: SW #22 Persuasive Paper Research Questions and Background (Section 9)
Events.Description:
This short writing assignment will help you get a head start on your persuasive research paper

Try to find a topic that you can research and write about for the next few weeks. Do some general research on Google or Wikipedia to learn more about your topic. 

Then, write 1-2 pages about the background of your topic, common arguments you have heard, and questions that you want to answer. You could also write about how your topic fits with the five stasis points.

For example, if you chose to write about homeschooling, you might include these questions and your initial answers:

Facts: How many children are being homeschooled in the USA?

Definition: What counts as home-schooling? What about online schools, dual-enrollment, etc. 

Cause/effect: Why is homeschooling becoming more popular? 

Evaluation: Does homeschooling help or harm kids academically? Does it help or harm kids socially?

Proposal: Should there be more government oversight for homeschooling? Should parents get tax money to help them educate their kids? Should parents choose homeschooling? 

 

As always, bring a paper copy to class.

Here are some topics that you might want to choose, but you are not limited to these options:

-Is online dating a good way to meet a spouse?  

-Is it better to grow up with lots of siblings or few siblings?

-Is it better to get married at a younger age or an older age? 

-What are the solutions to the drug and Fentanyl problems in the US?

-Should transgender athletes compete with female athletes? 

-Should states ban hormone blockers, cross-sex hormones, and/or sex-change surgeries for minors? 

-What can be done about illegal immigration?  

-Should the federal government forgive student loan debt? 

-What is the value of a college degree? 

-Is nuclear power safe and effective, or should nuclear power plants be shut down? 

-What are the effects of smartphones, screen time, and/or social media on mental health?

-Is physical discipline like spanking effective in parenting?

-Should marijuana be legalized recreationally in every state? 

-Should we raise the federal minimum wage to $15?

-Should states ban abortion? If so, at what stage in the pregnancy? How should abortion laws be enforced? 

-Should colleges practice affirmative action in admissions? Should employers use affirmative action in hiring? 

-What is the best solution for homelessness? Is "housing first" a good policy? 

-What is the best solution to crime? What are the merits of criminal justice reform, bail reform, and "harm reduction" policies? 

-Should California and other states ban the sale of new gas cars by 2035? Should the government continue to subsidize the sale of electric vehicles with tax breaks? 

-Should the government subsidize the sale of solar panels for homeowners? 

-What are the effects of religion on teenagers and young adults? 

-Should all states ban minors from tanning beds? 

-Should social media platforms censor speech? Should hate speech be banned? Should certain books be taken out of school libraries? 

-Is homeschooling good for kids? 

-What are the benefits or harms of standardized testing? 

-What forms of exercise are the most effective? Is weight training more effective than aerobic exercise? What about things like HIT, supplements, etc.? 

-What are the effects of gratitude on happiness?

Read chapter 4 of our book They Say / I Say. 

You can access a free online version of the book here: [https://archive.org/details/they-say-i-say-5th-edition/page/n1/mode/2upLinks to an external site.] (https://archive.org/details/they-say-i-say-5th-edition/page/n1/mode/2up) or here [https://archive.org/details/theysayisay3rdedition/page/n29/mode/2upLinks to an external site.] (https://archive.org/details/theysayisay3rdedition/page/n29/mode/2up)

For this short writing exercise, write an outline for your persuasive paper. Make it as detailed as you can at this stage of your writing process. 

You may want to use one of the following patterns to shape your outline:

Problem/Solution

First, define the problem

Then, offer your solution (you could compare your solution to other solutions that have been tried or proposed)

Best for a clear problem with many proposed solutions, like drug addiction.

 

Five Stasis Points

Fact

Definition

Cause/effect

Evaluation

Proposal

Best for a topic people don’t already know a lot about, like the Tigray rebellion

 

Delayed Thesis

Show both sides of the argument first, then give your opinion late in the paper

Best for emotionally charged controversies where both sides are stubborn, like abortion

 

They say / I say

Start with the opposing side

Best for contrarian takes and strong opinions, like birth rate decline

 

Traditional

Like the five-paragraph essay

Start with the thesis and support it with reasons and evidence

Best for a topic you have a strong opinion about, like gun control. You can deal with the naysayers later.

 

Evaluation based

Set up the criteria of evaluation

Best for evaluation arguments like “is homeschooling good for kids?”

 

Proposal based

Start with your proposal

Then defend your proposal from naysayers by talking about feasibility, justice, effectiveness, etc.

Best for proposals like “we should ban fracking”

Events.Summary: SW #24 Sources for the Persuasive Paper (Section 9)
Events.Description:
Write a 1-2 page paper with at least 6 sources, 4 of which should be peer-reviewed, academic articles.

For each source, include the MLA citation and a few sentences of summary about what the source says and where you might use it.

Useful resources include [scholar.google.com] (http://scholar.google.com) and [library.byui.edu] (http://library.byui.edu) 

As you search for sources, think about which sources will fit into which parts of your paper. 

Here are some of the ideas for outlining that we looked at in class:

Different ideas for organizing your paper:

Problem/Solution: Good for topics that not everyone knows are big problems

-A big chunk of the paper should establish the size/importance of the problem

-Then you give your solutions

-Naysayers could be saying “it’s not a real problem,” or “That solution won’t work”

5 Stasis Points: Good for most topics, especially if people are not aware of them

-Facts, definitions, cause and effect, evaluation, and proposal

-Consider ending with a proposal, no matter what organization you use

Evaluation or Proposal focus: good for specific topics

-For evaluation, establish criteria

-For proposal, show that your solution is better than the alternatives and feasible

Delayed Thesis: Good for highly controversial topics

-show pros and cons of both sides

-Eventually share what you think is the stronger side

They Say / I Say: Good for most topics, especially if there are a lot of opinions out there

-Start with what others are saying, respond like a conversation, deal with naysayers

Naysayer Focus: Good for controversial topics, or for readers who disagree with you

-Bring up and answer a series of naysayers

Traditional: works for many topics, especially if you have a lot of objective evidence

-Thesis, reasons, evidence

-Include naysayers

Here are some elements you might comment about:

* Catchy title

* Hook that grabs the reader's attention

* Try a story, image, statistic, question, strong opinion, imaginary scenario, etc. 

* Introduction that explains the experiment, why you picked it, and what your hypothesis was

* Quoting or referencing at least 3-4 sources

* Introduce your source

* Use an in-text citation with a parenthesis and the author's name and page number if there is one. Ex. (Smith 34).

* Explain the quote and any technical terms if needed

* Methods section that breaks down how you conducted the experiment

* Results section that shares what happened with your experiment. Be sure to have little stories and vivid details here as well as any numbers you collected

* Discussion section where you talk about what you will take away from your experiment and what you plan to do in the future. This is another good section for using your sources.
